summary: Napoleon is a large, fierce-looking Berkshire boar, who is not much of a talker but has a reputation for getting his own way. He is one of the two young boars who are pre-eminent among the pigs and is being bred up for sale by Mr. Jones. He is instrumental in leading the rebellion against Mr. Jones and takes a leading role in establishing the new order on the farm.

Napoleon is a large, fierce-looking Berkshire boar who is assertive, authoritative, and strategic. He is not much of a talker but has a reputation for getting his own way. He was initially bred for sale by Mr. Jones but later leads a rebellion against him, establishing a new order on the farm. Napoleon is manipulative, using fear tactics to justify special privileges for the pigs. He is also the apparent leader of the animals and is often in disagreement with Snowball, opposing his ideas and plans.

Napoleon is a large, fierce-looking Berkshire boar who is assertive, authoritative, and strategic. He is manipulative, cunning, and power-hungry, using fear tactics and manipulation to control the other animals on the farm. Initially against the idea of the windmill, he later takes credit for it, demonstrating his opportunistic nature. He uses dogs as his personal security force and changes the farm's commandments to suit his needs. He often disagrees with Snowball and blames him for the farm's problems. Despite his manipulative tactics, he is the apparent leader of the animals.

Napoleon is a large, fierce-looking Berkshire boar who is assertive, authoritative, and strategic. He is manipulative, cunning, and power-hungry, using fear tactics and manipulation to control the other animals on the farm. He is rarely seen in public, but when he does appear, he is always surrounded by his loyal dogs. Napoleon uses Mr. Whymper to spread false information about the farm's prosperity and is ruthless in his leadership, ordering the execution of animals he accuses of conspiring against him. He is also deceitful, pretending to negotiate with both Mr. Pilkington and Mr. Frederick while spreading rumors about both. Despite his manipulative and ruthless tactics, he is the apparent leader of the animals.

Napoleon is a large, fierce-looking Berkshire boar who is the assertive and authoritative leader of the farm. He is strategic, manipulative, and power-hungry, often using fear tactics and manipulation to control the other animals. Rarely seen in public, he is always surrounded by his loyal dogs when he does appear. He uses others to spread false information about the farm's prosperity and is ruthless in his leadership, even ordering the execution of animals he accuses of conspiring against him. Despite his deceitful tactics, he is the recognized leader of the animals. He is also selfish, prioritizing his own needs and desires over those of the other animals.

Napoleon is a mature, large, and fierce-looking Berkshire boar who is the authoritative leader of Animal Farm. He is strategic, manipulative, and power-hungry, often using fear tactics, manipulation, and deception to control the other animals. He rarely appears in public, but when he does, he is always surrounded by his loyal dogs who serve as his bodyguards. Despite his ruthless and selfish leadership, prioritizing his own needs over those of the other animals, he is respected and recognized as the leader by the other animals. He also uses others, particularly Squealer, to spread false information about the farm's prosperity.

Snowball is a more vivacious pig than Napoleon, quicker in speech and more inventive, but is not considered to have the same depth of character. He is also one of the two young boars who are pre-eminent among the pigs. He is instrumental in leading the rebellion against Mr. Jones and takes a leading role in establishing the new order on the farm.

Snowball is a highly active and intelligent pig who plays a significant role in the affairs of the farm. He is innovative and persuasive, often swaying the majority of the animals with his eloquent speeches. Snowball is also a brave leader, as seen in his leadership during the Battle of the Cowshed. He is deeply involved in planning for the farm's future and organizes the animals into committees. Despite his rivalry with Napoleon, another influential pig, Snowball's dedication to the farm and its inhabitants is evident.

Snowball is an intelligent and eloquent pig who serves as a leader on the farm. He is passionate about his ideas, particularly the construction of a windmill, which he fervently advocates for. However, his leadership is challenged by Napoleon, another pig leader who is assertive and manipulative. Their disagreements culminate in Snowball being chased off the farm by Napoleon's dogs, after which he is scapegoated for the farm's problems.

Snowball is a character who, despite not appearing directly in the story, plays a significant role as a scapegoat. He is blamed for every misfortune that befalls the farm, from major projects like the windmill's destruction to minor issues like the mixing of weed seeds with seed corn. His reputation is manipulated by Napoleon, who portrays him as a traitor and a menace, allegedly in league with the farm's human enemies. This character is often at odds with Napoleon, suggesting a difference in their leadership styles or ideologies.

Snowball is a character who, despite his significant contributions, is portrayed as a traitor and enemy to the farm. He is often blamed by Napoleon for any misfortunes or difficulties that the farm experiences, serving as a convenient scapegoat. Despite his exile, it is suggested that Snowball is living in luxury. His physical appearance is not detailed in the text, but his character is marked by the controversy and blame he attracts.

Snowball is a character from the past who once shared leadership with Napoleon on the farm. He is characterized as a symbol of hope and a different vision for the farm, which ultimately failed. He was driven out by Napoleon and is largely forgotten by the other animals, suggesting his influence and ideas did not have a lasting impact. His absence and the contrast with Napoleon's ruthless and manipulative leadership style suggest that Snowball may have been a more compassionate and idealistic leader.

Boxer is an enormous beast, nearly eighteen hands high, and as strong as any two ordinary horses put together. A white stripe down his nose gives him a somewhat stupid appearance, and in fact he is not of first-rate intelligence, but he is universally respected for his steadiness of character and tremendous powers of work. He is one of the most faithful disciples of the pigs and is unfailing in his attendance at the secret meetings in the barn.

Boxer is a hardworking and strong horse, admired by all for his dedication and willingness to take on extra labor. He is loyal, somewhat naive, and adopts 'I will work harder' as his personal motto. Despite his strength, he is gentle and does not wish to harm anyone, including humans. He is not directly related to Napoleon, the Berkshire boar, but is a significant part of the new order established on the farm after the rebellion against Mr. Jones.

Boxer is a hard-working and loyal horse on the farm, known for his physical strength and dedication. Despite not being very intelligent, he is a firm believer in Napoleon's leadership and the commandments. He is a tireless worker, often pushing himself beyond his limits, even when injured. His commitment is particularly evident in his significant contribution to the construction of the windmill.

Boxer is a physically strong and brave character, known for his hard work and loyalty to the farm. Despite facing hardships, he remains dedicated to the cause. However, his naivety makes him susceptible to manipulation, particularly by Napoleon, whose version of events he accepts without question. His approach to problems is to work harder, demonstrating his commitment but also revealing his lack of critical thinking.

Boxer is a large, strong character, characterized by his hardworking and loyal nature. Despite his physical prowess, he is naive and easily manipulated, particularly by the more cunning animals on the farm, such as Napoleon. He is self-sacrificing, continuing to work hard even when injured. His dedication to the farm's success is unwavering, but his trust in the leadership makes him vulnerable to exploitation.

Boxer is a physically powerful and hardworking horse, characterized by his unwavering loyalty and dedication to the ideals of Animal Farm. Despite his strength, his lack of intelligence makes him susceptible to manipulation, particularly by the farm's authoritative leader, Napoleon. His tragic end, being sold to a glue factory when his usefulness wanes, symbolizes the exploitation and betrayal of the working class. He is identifiable by a distinctive white stripe down his nose.
